author: E-mail: crimescene@nytimes.com Twitter: @mwilsonnyt
body: ''I would know it,'' Esther Davis told me back in May, a few days after thieves had made off with her wrought-iron gate that squeaked open and shut on Vanderbilt Avenue in Brooklyn for almost all of her 53 years. Adding to her frustrations was the fact that the thieves stole a bunch of gates that day; she was one of many victims standing in front
title: CRIME SCENE; Diverging Paths of Victims Can Run Into Dead Ends

author: E-mail: crimescene@nytimes.com
body: While politics is usually the matchmaker in these things, this time it had nothing to do with the strange bedfellows found at ''The Beach.'' On one side is a club of middle-aged and elderly Roman Catholic men, and on the other is a tattoo parlor that uses crucifixes in lieu of the t's in its name. The mysterious stranger who brought them together:
title: CRIME SCENE; A Tattoo Parlor, a Knights of Columbus Hall and a Burglar Led Into Temptation

body: Two years ago, St. Joseph's Church in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, seemed to be headed for extinction. Attendance at Sunday Masses had fallen below 100. The 159-year-old parish's buildings were crumbling and its coffers were empty. Today, the scaffolding outside bustles with workers. Sundays draw more than 300 worshipers, many of them families with
title: NOW ARRIVING; Mexicans Fill Pews, Even as the Church Is Slow to Adapt

body: JOE GIORDANO should have seen it coming. He should have noticed the evil glint in the young woman's eyes. She was fixated on her ex-boyfriend's smart tuxedo and innocent smile. But there was no time. She picked up her weapon and ''all of a sudden she started unloading on this guy,'' Mr. Giordano recalled, his eyes wide as he recounted what had
title: NEIGHBORHOOD JOINT | GERRITSEN BEACH; Armed And Ready To 'Paint'

body: A street level shop in the Gerritsen Beach neighborhood of Brooklyn lays claim to being the only paintball supply shop in the borough.
title: Neighborhood Joint | The Paint Spot

body: Daniel Cavanagh was nervous. He paced the living room of his duplex apartment collecting his things: a large digital camera, an iPhone, a black leather jacket. ''I'm about to get crushed,'' he said, running his hands through his hair. Then Mr. Cavanagh, 26, drove the three blocks to St. James Evangelical Lutheran Church -- the meeting place of the
title: GERRITSEN BEACH JOURNAL; Not Quite a Reporter, but Raking Muck and Reaping Wrath
